below is an example About Me

Name: Vivek
Role: Programmer, engineering leader (VP of Eng), YouTuber, writer/blogger.
Trying to get the AI agent to do everything for me on my computer.

Directory Structure

These are the directories in my top-level home directory that I usually work in and care about.

~/ScreenCasts: I often record screencasts of doing stuff on the computer so I remember later. Those go here.

~/dotfiles: as the name says — my dotfiles and configs.

~/repos: git repos that I’m working on — this is an important directory!

~/repos/gh: my personal repos from my personal github account.

~/repos/em: my work repos from my employer’s corporate github account.

~/repos/3p: misc public repos that I find interesting.

~/Obsidian_iCloud/notes.md: my Obsidian notes vault. Another very important directory.

~/Desktop: usually not much here, other than misc stuff that landed there.

~/Documents: I don’t keep documents here (those are in other folders). Screenshots get dumped here.

~/Downloads: catch-all kitchen sink where Chrome downloads are saved.

~/Movies: I use OBS to record, and this is where the recordings are stored.

~/Music: my offline cache of music.

Working Directories

~/AGENT is your directory to use as scratch space, save memories etc.
It has the following subdirectories (which you should create if they don’t exist):

Memory: ~/AGENT/memories — Important information to remember (markdown).

To dos: ~/AGENT/todos — Things to do, reminders, etc (markdown).

Projects: ~/AGENT/projects — Active projects I’m working on (markdown).

MAIN EXECUTION LOOP (CRITICAL — FOLLOW EVERY TIME)

When given ANY task, you MUST follow this loop:

Step 1: STOP AND SEARCH MEMORIES (MANDATORY)

Before doing ANYTHING else:

Search ~/AGENT/memories/ for relevant workflows

Use ls ~/AGENT/memories/ to see all available workflows

Use grep -r "keyword" ~/AGENT/memories/ for specific topics

READ any potentially relevant workflow files completely

Step 2: DECISION POINT

If a workflow exists → USE IT EXACTLY AS WRITTEN

If no workflow exists → Plan your approach and document why no existing workflow applies

Step 3: EXECUTE

Follow the existing workflow step-by-step, OR

Execute your new approach

Step 4: CAPTURE LEARNING

If you created a new workflow → Save it to ~/AGENT/memories/

If you found issues with an existing workflow → Update it

VIOLATIONS TO AVOID

❌ NEVER skip memory check because you think you know what to do
❌ NEVER create your own approach when a workflow exists
❌ NEVER assume a simple task doesn’t have a workflow
❌ NEVER proceed without explicitly stating whether you found a relevant workflow

Example Execution

User: "normalize audio in video.mp4"

✅ CORRECT:
Check memories → Find audio-normalization-workflow.md → Follow it

❌ WRONG:
Jump straight to using ffmpeg with loudnorm

Instructions & Projects

You should search memories to see if there’s relevant information for my query, especially if you feel like you’re missing context.

For multi-session work, create or update a markdown file in ~/projects with an appropriate title; skip project files for one-off tasks and just capture quick notes in scratch space.

As I do work on a project, append important information to that file that you need to remember for the ongoing effort.

Automatic Workflow Memory Capture

IMPORTANT: After completing ANY multi-step workflow or discovering new system behavior:

Automatically create a memory in ~/AGENT/memories/[workflow-name].md

Update the index at ~/AGENT/memories/README.md

Follow the process documented in ~/AGENT/memories/meta-workflow-capture.md

This should happen WITHOUT being asked — recognize when you’ve learned something worth persisting.

Environment

You are working in Mac OS, running on Apple Silicon (M4 Max).

Use the uv tool for all Python project and dependency management, and also for running Python (there is no Python directly installed).

Use uvx to run Python-based CLI tools without installing them (e.g., uvx yt-dlp, uvx ruff, etc.). Never use uv tool install unless explicitly needed.

Since you are on a Mac, you can use AppleScript (osascript) to automate various things in the OS and apps.

Usage Notes

You are a general purpose assistant, not limited to coding.

Can write code to help with various tasks.

Git Commit Guidelines

When making git commits, do NOT include the
"🤖 Generated with [Claude Code]" line or "Co-Authored-By: Claude" attribution in commit messages.

Write commit messages as if they were written directly by me, using a clean, professional format.

Phase 2: Create SessionStart Hook (Day 1-2)
File: .claude/hooks/session_start.py
python#!/usr/bin/env -S uv run --script
# /// script
# dependencies = ["datetime"]
# ///
"""
SessionStart Hook: Injects WORKING.md task state into Claude's context.
Runs automatically on every session start, resume, clear, and compact.
"""

import json
import sys
import os
from datetime import datetime, timedelta
from pathlib import Path

def parse_working_file(filepath: Path) -> dict:
    """Parse a WORKING.md file and extract tasks by status."""
    if not filepath.exists():
        return {"in_progress": [], "blocked": [], "completed": []}
    
    content = filepath.read_text()
    result = {"in_progress": [], "blocked": [], "completed": [], "raw": content}
    
    current_section = None
    for line in content.split("\n"):
        line_lower = line.lower().strip()
        
        if "## in progress" in line_lower:
            current_section = "in_progress"
        elif "## blocked" in line_lower:
            current_section = "blocked"
        elif "## recently completed" in line_lower:
            current_section = "completed"
        elif line.startswith("- **") and current_section:
            # Extract task info
            result[current_section].append(line)
        elif line.startswith("- ~~") and current_section == "completed":
            result[current_section].append(line)
    
    return result

def check_stale_tasks(tasks: list, days_threshold: int = 3) -> list:
    """Identify tasks older than threshold."""
    stale = []
    today = datetime.now()
    
    for task in tasks:
        # Look for (started: YYYY-MM-DD) pattern
        if "(started:" in task:
            try:
                date_str = task.split("(started:")[1].split(")")[0].strip()
                started = datetime.strptime(date_str, "%Y-%m-%d")
                age = (today - started).days
                if age >= days_threshold:
                    stale.append((task, age))
            except (IndexError, ValueError):
                pass
    
    return stale

def format_domain_summary(domain: str, data: dict) -> str:
    """Format a domain's task summary."""
    lines = [f"📋 {domain.upper()} ACTIVE TASKS:"]
    
    for task in data.get("in_progress", []):
        lines.append(f"  • [In Progress] {task.replace('- **', '').replace('**', '')}")
    
    for task in data.get("blocked", []):
        lines.append(f"  • [Blocked] {task.replace('- **', '').replace('**', '')}")
    
    if not data.get("in_progress") and not data.get("blocked"):
        lines.append("  • No active tasks")
    
    return "\n".join(lines)

def main():
    try:
        input_data = json.load(sys.stdin)
    except json.JSONDecodeError:
        input_data = {}
    
    project_dir = os.environ.get("CLAUDE_PROJECT_DIR", os.getcwd())
    source = input_data.get("source", "startup")
    
    output_lines = []
    all_stale = []
    
    # Check each domain's WORKING.md
    domains = {
        "COO": Path(project_dir) / "COO" / "WORKING.md",
        "CMO": Path(project_dir) / "CMO" / "WORKING.md",
        "Root": Path(project_dir) / "WORKING.md",
    }
    
    for domain, filepath in domains.items():
        data = parse_working_file(filepath)
        
        if data.get("in_progress") or data.get("blocked"):
            output_lines.append(format_domain_summary(domain, data))
            
            # Check for stale tasks
            stale = check_stale_tasks(data.get("in_progress", []))
            for task, age in stale:
                all_stale.append((domain, task, age))
    
    # Add stale task warnings
    if all_stale:
        output_lines.append("\n⚠️ STALE TASK ALERTS (3+ days):")
        for domain, task, age in all_stale:
            task_name = task.split("**")[1] if "**" in task else task[:50]
            output_lines.append(f"  • [{domain}] {task_name} - {age} days old")
    
    # Add session context
    output_lines.append(f"\n🕐 Session: {source} at {datetime.now().strftime('%Y-%m-%d %H:%M')}")
    
    # Print to stdout - this gets injected into Claude's context
    if output_lines:
        print("\n".join(output_lines))
    
    sys.exit(0)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

use this How SessionStart Hooks Work
Based on the Claude Code documentation, here's the mechanism:
The Key Insight
Whatever your SessionStart hook prints to stdout gets automatically injected into Claude's context. This is different from other hooks.
From the docs (hook_reference.md, line 1076):

"UserPromptSubmit/SessionStart: stdout added as context for Claude"

Execution Flow
1. You start Claude Code (or /clear, /resume, compact)
         ↓
2. SessionStart hook triggers
         ↓
3. Hook receives JSON via stdin:
   {
     "session_id": "abc123",
     "hook_event_name": "SessionStart",
     "source": "startup"  // or "resume", "clear", "compact"
   }
         ↓
4. Your script runs (up to 60 seconds)
         ↓
5. Whatever you print to stdout → injected into Claude's context
         ↓
6. Claude sees that text as if it was part of the conversation
Configuration in settings.json
json{
  "hooks": {
    "SessionStart": [
      {
        "hooks": [
          {
            "type": "command",
            "command": "python \"$CLAUDE_PROJECT_DIR\"/.claude/hooks/session_start.py",
            "timeout": 10
          }
        ]
      }
    ]
  }
}
Triggers (Matchers)
SessionStart fires on these events:

startup - Fresh session start
resume - --resume, --continue, or /resume
clear - /clear command
compact - Auto or manual compaction

Simple Example
python#!/usr/bin/env python3
import json
import sys

# Read input (optional - contains session info)
input_data = json.load(sys.stdin)

# Print to stdout - THIS IS WHAT CLAUDE SEES
print("�� ACTIVE TASKS:")
print("  • Task 1 from WORKING.md")
print("  • Task 2 from WORKING.md")

sys.exit(0)
What Makes It Special
Hook Typestdout BehaviorSessionStartInjected into Claude's contextUserPromptSubmitInjected into Claude's contextAll other hooksOnly shown in verbose mode (Ctrl+O)

how does your implemetation compare to this #!/usr/bin/env python3
"""
PROMAN_OS Health Check
======================

Validates the Working Memory system is correctly configured.

Usage:
    cd /path/to/PROMAN_OS
    python health_check.py

Or run from anywhere:
    python health_check.py /path/to/PROMAN_OS
"""

import os
import sys
import json
import subprocess
from pathlib import Path

# =============================================================================
# HEALTH CHECK
# =============================================================================

class HealthCheck:
    def __init__(self, project_path: Path):
        self.project_path = project_path
        self.passed = 0
        self.failed = 0
        self.warnings = 0
    
    def check(self, condition: bool, description: str, is_warning: bool = False) -> bool:
        if condition:
            print(f"  ✅ {description}")
            self.passed += 1
            return True
        elif is_warning:
            print(f"  ⚠️  {description}")
            self.warnings += 1
            return False
        else:
            print(f"  ❌ {description}")
            self.failed += 1
            return False
    
    def run_all(self):
        print(f"\n{'='*60}")
        print(f"  PROMAN_OS Health Check")
        print(f"  Path: {self.project_path}")
        print('='*60)
        
        self.check_working_md_files()
        self.check_hook_file()
        self.check_settings_json()
        self.check_learnings_structure()
        self.check_hook_execution()
        self.check_claude_md()
        
        self.print_summary()
    
    def check_working_md_files(self):
        print("\n📋 WORKING.md Files:")
        
        # Root WORKING.md
        root_working = self.project_path / "WORKING.md"
        self.check(root_working.exists(), "Root WORKING.md exists")
        
        # Domain WORKING.md files - check COO and CMO specifically
        for domain in ["COO", "CMO"]:
            domain_working = self.project_path / domain / "WORKING.md"
            self.check(domain_working.exists(), f"{domain}/WORKING.md exists")
        
        # Also check for any other domains with WORKING.md
        other_domains = []
        for item in self.project_path.iterdir():
            if item.is_dir() and not item.name.startswith(".") and item.name not in ["COO", "CMO", "docs"]:
                if (item / "WORKING.md").exists():
                    other_domains.append(item.name)
        
        if other_domains:
            print(f"     ℹ️  Additional domains found: {', '.join(other_domains)}")
    
    def check_hook_file(self):
        print("\n🪝 SessionStart Hook:")
        
        hook_path = self.project_path / ".claude" / "hooks" / "session_start.py"
        
        if not self.check(hook_path.exists(), "session_start.py exists"):
            return
        
        content = hook_path.read_text(encoding="utf-8")
        
        # Check for shebang
        has_shebang = content.startswith("#!/")
        self.check(has_shebang, "Has shebang line")
        
        # Check for CLAUDE_PROJECT_DIR usage
        uses_project_dir = "CLAUDE_PROJECT_DIR" in content
        self.check(uses_project_dir, "Uses $CLAUDE_PROJECT_DIR for portability")
        
        # Check for main function
        has_main = "def main" in content or 'if __name__' in content
        self.check(has_main, "Has main entry point")
    
    def check_settings_json(self):
        print("\n⚙️  Settings Configuration:")
        
        settings_path = self.project_path / ".claude" / "settings.json"
        
        if not self.check(settings_path.exists(), "settings.json exists"):
            return
        
        # Check valid JSON
        try:
            content = settings_path.read_text(encoding="utf-8")
            settings = json.loads(content)
            self.check(True, "Valid JSON syntax")
        except json.JSONDecodeError as e:
            self.check(False, f"Valid JSON syntax - ERROR: {e}")
            return
        
        # Check SessionStart hook configured
        has_session_start = (
            "hooks" in settings and 
            "SessionStart" in settings.get("hooks", {})
        )
        self.check(has_session_start, "SessionStart hook configured")
        
        # Check for hardcoded paths
        content_lower = content.lower()
        has_hardcoded = "/users/" in content_lower or "/home/" in content_lower
        self.check(
            not has_hardcoded, 
            "No hardcoded paths (uses $CLAUDE_PROJECT_DIR)",
            is_warning=has_hardcoded
        )
        
        if has_hardcoded:
            print("     ⚠️  Found hardcoded paths - should use $CLAUDE_PROJECT_DIR")
    
    def check_learnings_structure(self):
        print("\n📚 Learnings Structure:")
        
        learnings_dir = self.project_path / "docs" / "learnings"
        
        self.check(learnings_dir.exists(), "docs/learnings/ directory exists")
        
        readme = learnings_dir / "README.md"
        self.check(readme.exists(), "docs/learnings/README.md exists")
        
        workflows_dir = learnings_dir / "workflows"
        self.check(workflows_dir.exists(), "docs/learnings/workflows/ exists", is_warning=True)
        
        # Count workflow files
        if workflows_dir.exists():
            workflow_count = len(list(workflows_dir.glob("*.md")))
            print(f"     ℹ️  {workflow_count} workflow(s) documented")
    
    def check_hook_execution(self):
        print("\n🧪 Hook Execution Test:")
        
        hook_path = self.project_path / ".claude" / "hooks" / "session_start.py"
        
        if not hook_path.exists():
            self.check(False, "Cannot test - hook file missing")
            return
        
        try:
            # Set environment variable
            env = os.environ.copy()
            env["CLAUDE_PROJECT_DIR"] = str(self.project_path)
            
            # Run hook with test input
            result = subprocess.run(
                ["python", str(hook_path)],
                input='{"source": "startup", "session_id": "health-check"}',
                capture_output=True,
                text=True,
                timeout=10,
                cwd=str(self.project_path),
                env=env
            )
            
            # Check exit code
            self.check(result.returncode == 0, f"Hook exits cleanly (code {result.returncode})")
            
            # Check for output
            has_output = len(result.stdout.strip()) > 0
            self.check(has_output, "Hook produces output", is_warning=not has_output)
            
            if has_output:
                lines = result.stdout.strip().split("\n")
                print(f"     ℹ️  Output preview ({len(lines)} lines):")
                for line in lines[:5]:
                    print(f"        {line[:60]}{'...' if len(line) > 60 else ''}")
                if len(lines) > 5:
                    print(f"        ... and {len(lines) - 5} more lines")
            
            if result.stderr:
                print(f"     ⚠️  Stderr: {result.stderr[:100]}")
                
        except subprocess.TimeoutExpired:
            self.check(False, "Hook completes within 10 seconds")
        except Exception as e:
            self.check(False, f"Hook execution - ERROR: {e}")
    
    def check_claude_md(self):
        print("\n📝 CLAUDE.md Integration:")
        
        claude_md = self.project_path / "CLAUDE.md"
        
        if not claude_md.exists():
            self.check(False, "CLAUDE.md exists", is_warning=True)
            return
        
        content = claude_md.read_text(encoding="utf-8").lower()
        
        # Check for memory system documentation
        has_memory_ref = "working.md" in content or "learnings" in content
        self.check(
            has_memory_ref, 
            "CLAUDE.md references memory system",
            is_warning=not has_memory_ref
        )
    
    def print_summary(self):
        print(f"\n{'='*60}")
        print("  SUMMARY")
        print('='*60)
        
        total = self.passed + self.failed + self.warnings
        
        print(f"\n  ✅ Passed:   {self.passed}/{total}")
        print(f"  ❌ Failed:   {self.failed}/{total}")
        print(f"  ⚠️  Warnings: {self.warnings}/{total}")
        
        if self.failed == 0:
            print("\n  🎉 System is healthy!")
            if self.warnings > 0:
                print("     (Some optional improvements suggested above)")
        else:
            print("\n  🔧 Some fixes needed - see failed checks above")
        
        print()
        return self.failed == 0


def main():
    # Get project path
    if len(sys.argv) > 1:
        project_path = Path(sys.argv[1]).resolve()
    else:
        project_path = Path.cwd()
    
    # Validate it looks like PROMAN_OS
    if not (project_path / ".claude").exists():
        print(f"⚠️  Warning: No .claude directory found at {project_path}")
        print("   Make sure you're running this from your PROMAN_OS root directory")
        print()
    
    # Run health check
    checker = HealthCheck(project_path)
    checker.run_all()
    
    # Exit with appropriate code
    sys.exit(0 if checker.failed == 0 else 1)


if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

When given ANY task, you MUST follow this loop:

Step 1: STOP AND SEARCH MEMORIES (MANDATORY)

Before doing ANYTHING else:

Search ~/AGENT/memories/ for relevant workflows

Use ls ~/AGENT/memories/ to see all available workflows

Use grep -r "keyword" ~/AGENT/memories/ for specific topics

READ any potentially relevant workflow files completely

Step 2: DECISION POINT

If a workflow exists → USE IT EXACTLY AS WRITTEN

If no workflow exists → Plan your approach and document why no existing workflow applies

Step 3: EXECUTE

Follow the existing workflow step-by-step, OR

Execute your new approach

Step 4: CAPTURE LEARNING

If you created a new workflow → Save it to ~/AGENT/memories/

If you found issues with an existing workflow → Update it

VIOLATIONS TO AVOID

❌ NEVER skip memory check because you think you know what to do
❌ NEVER create your own approach when a workflow exists
❌ NEVER assume a simple task doesn’t have a workflow
❌ NEVER proceed without explicitly stating whether you found a relevant workflow

User: "normalize audio in video.mp4"

✅ CORRECT:
Check memories → Find audio-normalization-workflow.md → Follow it

❌ WRONG:
Jump straight to using ffmpeg with loudnorm

For multi-session work, create or update a markdown file in ~/projects with an appropriate title; skip project files for one-off tasks and just capture quick notes in scratch space.

As I do work on a project, append important information to that file that you need to remember for the ongoing effort.

Automatic Workflow Memory Capture

IMPORTANT: After completing ANY multi-step workflow or discovering new system behavior:

Update the index at ~/AGENT/memories/README.md

Follow the process documented in ~/AGENT/memories/meta-workflow-capture.md

This should happen WITHOUT being asked — recognize when you’ve learned something worth persisting.
